verses.translation: The Way that can be put in­to words is not the con­stant Way.

verses.original: 天下皆知美之爲美，斯惡已；
verses.translation: As soon as eve­ry­one in the world knows beau­ty as beau­ty, there is al­read­y ug­li­ness.

verses.original: 皆知善之爲善，斯不善矣。
verses.translation: As soon as eve­ry­one knows good as good, there is bad.
Be­ing and non­be­ing pro­duce each oth­er;
dif­fi­cult and eas­y com­plete each oth­er;
long and short shape each oth­er;
high and low fill each oth­er;
note and voice har­mo­nize with each oth­er;
front and back fol­low each oth­er:
these are con­stant.
There­fore the sage dwells in the work of nonforced ac­tion,
and practices word­less teach­ing.
All things a­rise, but he does­nʼt start them;
he acts on their be­half, but does­nʼt make them de­pend­ent;
he succeeds, but does­nʼt dwell on it.
Itʼs on­ly be­cause he does­nʼt dwell on it, that it does­nʼt leave.
By not el­e­vat­ing the wor­thy, you keep the peo­ple from con­ten­tion.

verses.original: 不貴難得之貨，使民不爲盜；
verses.translation: By not valuing rare treasures, you keep the peo­ple from steal­ing.
By not displaying what is de­sir­a­ble, you keep the peo­ple from con­fu­sion.

verses.original: 是以聖人之治也，虛其心，實其腹；弱其志，強其骨。
verses.translation: There­fore the sage governs by clear­ing the peopleʼs minds, but fill­ing their bellies; weakening their ambitions, but strengthening their bones.
He con­stant­ly keeps the peo­ple with­out cun­ning and with­out desires
so that the intellectuals wonʼt dare to med­dle.
Act with­out forc­ing, then eve­ry­thing is governed prop­er­ly.
The sage puts him­self in the back­ground yet finds him­self in the fore­ground;
puts him­self out of mind yet finds him­self cared for.
Is­nʼt it be­cause heʼs self­less that
heʼs a­ble to a­chieve his self-interest?
The highest good is like wa­ter.
Waterʼs good­ness is that it benefits all things,
yet it strives to dwell in the places that the crowd hates,
there­fore it co­mes close to the Way.
In a dwell­ing, its good­ness is lo­ca­tion;
in a mind, depth;
in giv­ing, be­ing like Heav­en;
in speak­ing, sin­cer­i­ty;
in gov­ern­ment, or­der;
in han­dling af­fairs, a­bil­i­ty;
in ac­tion, time­li­ness.
Be­cause there is no con­ten­tion, there is no blame.
If you hold and o­ver­fill a cup, itʼs not as good as stop­ping short.
If you ham­mer and oversharpen a blade, you canʼt main­tain it for long.
If gold and jade fill your rooms, no one is a­ble to pro­tect it.
If sta­tus and wealth lead to ar­ro­gance, you bring dis­as­ter up­on your­self.
When the work is done, with­draw; this is the Way of Heav­en.
Thir­ty spokes come to­geth­er at one hub,
but itʼs the emp­ti­ness in­side the hub that makes it use­ful to the cart.
We form clay in­to a pot,
but itʼs the emp­ti­ness in­side that makes the clay pot use­ful.
We chis­el out doors and windows to make a room,
but itʼs the emp­ti­ness in­side that makes the room use­ful.
There­fore, what is pres­ent brings ben­e­fit,
but what is ab­sent makes it use­ful.
In an­tiq­ui­ty, those who were good at the Way
were sub­tle, won­der­ful, mys­te­ri­ous, pen­e­trat­ing, and too deep to know.

verses.original: 夫唯不可識，故強爲之容：
verses.translation: Be­cause they canʼt be known, weʼre forced to de­scribe their ap­pear­ance:
Hes­i­tant, as if cross­ing a riv­er in win­ter.
A­lert, as if fearing the neighbors on all sides.
Sol­emn, like a visiting guest.
Yield­ing, like ice a­bout to melt.
Gen­u­ine, like un­carved wood.
O­paque, like mud­dy wa­ter.
Vast, like a val­ley.
If mud­dy wa­ter is still, it grad­u­al­ly becomes clear.
If some­thing at rest is moved, it grad­u­al­ly co­mes to life.
With the ver­y best rulers, those be­low on­ly know that the rulers ex­ist,
the next best are the rulers they love and praise,
next are the rulers they fear,
and the worst are the rulers they des­pise.

verses.original: 成功遂事，而百姓皆謂：「我自然」。
verses.translation: When the task is ac­com­plished and the work is done, all the com­mon peo­ple say, “We did it our­selves.”
Itʼs when the great Way is a­ban­doned that be­nev­o­lence and right­eous­ness ap­pear.
Itʼs when learn­ing and clev­er­ness e­merge that the great hy­poc­ri­sy appears.
Itʼs when fam­i­ly relationships are not har­mo­ni­ous that fil­ial pi­e­ty and pa­ren­tal com­pas­sion ap­pear.
Itʼs when the coun­try is con­fused and cha­ot­ic that up­right officials ap­pear.
Dem­on­strate plain­ness, em­brace sim­plic­i­ty, have lit­tle self­ish­ness and few desires.
Bent o­ver then pre­served whole;
crook­ed then straight;
hol­low then filled;
worn out then renewed;
hav­ing lit­tle then sat­is­fied;
hav­ing much then con­fused.

verses.original: 是以聖人執一以爲天下牧。
verses.translation: There­fore the sage holds to the one and becomes shep­herd to the world.
He does­nʼt pro­mote him­self, so heʼs ac­knowl­edged.
He does­nʼt dis­play him­self, so he shines bright­ly.
He does­nʼt brag a­bout him­self, so he has mer­it.
Heʼs not boast­ful, so he can en­dure.

verses.original: 夫唯不爭，故莫能與之爭。
verses.translation: Itʼs on­ly be­cause he does­nʼt con­tend that no one can con­tend with him.
Itʼs nat­u­ral to speak rare­ly.
A vi­o­lent wind does­nʼt last all morn­ing.
A tor­ren­tial rain does­nʼt last all day.

verses.original: 天地而弗能久，又況於人乎？
verses.translation: If heav­en and earth canʼt sus­tain it for long, how much less can man?
He who blows hard canʼt stand.
He who promotes him­self is­nʼt ac­knowl­edged.
He who displays him­self does­nʼt shine bright­ly.
He who brags a­bout him­self has no mer­it.
He who boasts a­bout him­self wonʼt en­dure.

verses.original: 物或惡之，故者欲者弗居。
verses.translation: These are so de­spised that e­ven those who want things donʼt a­bide them.
A skill­ful trav­el­er leaves no ruts or tracks.
A skill­ful speak­er makes no slips or gaffes.
A skill­ful count­er needs no tallies or papers.

verses.original: 聖人恆善救人；而無棄人；
verses.translation: The sage is al­ways skill­ful at sav­ing peo­ple, and nev­er abandons any­one;
with things, he nev­er abandons val­u­a­ble prop­er­ty.
Skill­ful peo­ple are the teachers of skill­ful peo­ple;
un­skilled peo­ple are the raw ma­te­ri­als of skill­ful peo­ple.

verses.original: 不貴其師，不愛其資，雖知乎大迷。
verses.translation: He who does­nʼt val­ue his teach­er and cher­ish his raw ma­te­ri­als is great­ly con­fused, no mat­ter how clev­er he is.
Those who want to take the world and rule it,
I see that they wonʼt suc­ceed.
The world is a sa­cred ves­sel,
and it canʼt be ruled.
Those who rule it ru­in it.
Those who hold it lose it.
Itʼs the na­ture of things that some lead and some fol­low,
some blow hot and some blow cold,
some are strong and some are weak,
some cul­ti­vate and some de­te­ri­o­rate.

verses.original: 是以聖人去甚，去泰，去奢。
verses.translation: There­fore the sage avoids extremes, ar­ro­gance, and ex­trav­a­gance.

verses.original: 以道佐人主，不以兵強於天下，
verses.translation: Those with the Way who as­sist the rul­er donʼt use the force of arms to con­quer the world;
such methods would on­ly back­fire.
Wher­ev­er armies camp, brambles and thorns will grow.
A skill­ful lead­er achieves results then stops,
and does­nʼt use the oc­ca­sion to sieze pow­er.
He achieves results with­out ar­ro­gance.
He achieves results with­out prais­ing his deeds.
He achieves results with­out boasting.
He achieves results on­ly as a last re­sort.
The mil­i­tar­y is an om­i­nous in­stru­ment.

verses.original: 物或惡之，故有欲者弗居。
verses.translation: Itʼs so de­spised that e­ven those who want things donʼt a­bide it.
The mil­i­tar­y is an om­i­nous in­stru­ment,
so on­ly use it as a last re­sort;
with calm de­tach­ment is best.
Donʼt glo­ri­fy it;
to glo­ri­fy it would be to de­light in kill­ing peo­ple.

verses.original: 夫樂殺人，不可以得志於天下矣。
verses.translation: He who delights in kill­ing peo­ple canʼt a­chieve his ambitions in the world.
When man­y peo­ple have been killed,
weep for them with sor­row.
When the war has been won, treat it like a fu­ner­al cer­e­mo­ny.
He who knows others is in­tel­li­gent;
he who knows him­self is enlightened.
He who overcomes others is force­ful;
he who overcomes him­self is pow­er­ful.
He who knows con­tent­ment is rich.
The Way floats and drifts;
it can go left or right.
When the task is ac­com­plished and the work is done, it claims no cred­it.
All things turn to it
and yet it does­nʼt act as their mas­ter,
so it can be called a small thing.
All things turn to it
and yet it does­nʼt act as their mas­ter,
so it can be called a great thing.
Thatʼs why the sage is a­ble to ac­com­plish great things:

verses.original: 以其不爲大也，故能成大。
verses.translation: he does­nʼt try to do great things, there­fore he accomplishes great things.
Com­ing to you, the world suffers no harm, but finds safe­ty and peace.
Pass­ing travelers will stop for mu­sic and food.
But if the Way were de­scribed,
it would seem in­sip­id and with­out fla­vor.
When you look at it, itʼs not suf­fi­cient to be seen;
when you lis­ten to it, itʼs not suf­fi­cient to be heard;
yet when you use it, it canʼt be exhausted.
If you want to shrink some­thing,
it must first be ex­pand­ed;
if you want to weak­en some­thing,
it must first be strengthened;
if you want to leave some­thing,
it must first be joined;
if you want to take some­thing a­way,
it must first be giv­en.
A man of su­pe­ri­or vir­tue does­nʼt cling to vir­tue,
there­fore he has true vir­tue.
A man of su­pe­ri­or vir­tue acts with­out force,
and with­out an a­gen­da.
There­fore, af­ter los­ing the Way there is vir­tue;
af­ter los­ing vir­tue there is be­nev­o­lence;
af­ter los­ing be­nev­o­lence there is right­eous­ness;
af­ter los­ing right­eous­ness there is pro­pri­e­ty.
As for pro­pri­e­ty, itʼs a thin ve­neer of loy­al­ty and sin­cer­i­ty,
and the be­gin­ning of dis­or­der.
There­fore a tru­ly great man dwells in the thick sub­stance,
not in the thin ve­neer;
in the fruit, not in the flow­er.
The softest, most pli­a­ble thing in the world
runs rough­shod o­ver the hardest, most sol­id thing in the world.
That which has no sub­stance enters in­to that which has no openings.

verses.original: 吾是以知無爲之有益也。
verses.translation: Thatʼs how I know the benefits of nonforced ac­tion.
Teachings that use no words,
and the benefits of nonforced ac­tion:
few in the world can un­der­stand them.
Ex­ces­sive at­tach­ment co­mes at great cost,
and great ac­cu­mu­la­tion leads to heav­y loss.
There­fore, know­ing con­tent­ment avoids dis­grace,
and know­ing when to stop avoids dan­ger;
thus you can en­dure for a long time.
When the world has the Way,
fi­ne hors­es are rel­e­gat­ed to fer­ti­liz­ing the fields.
When the world lacks the Way,
warhorses are bred just out­side the cit­y walls.
There is no greater crime than de­sire.
There is no greater dis­as­ter than be­ing dis­con­tent.
There is no greater fault than want­ing more.
There­fore the sat­is­fac­tion that co­mes from be­ing con­tent is last­ing sat­is­fac­tion.
You donʼt have to go out the door to know the world.
You donʼt have to peek out the win­dow to know the Way of Heav­en.

verses.original: 其出也彌遠者，其知彌尟。
verses.translation: The far­ther you go, the less you know.
There­fore the sage does­nʼt trav­el but knows;
does­nʼt look, but discerns;
and does­nʼt do, but succeeds.
He who pursues learn­ing gains some­thing each day.
He who hears the Way loses some­thing each day.
He loses, and loses a­gain, un­til he acts with­out force.
He acts with­out force and yet noth­ing is left un­done.
If you want to rule the world, con­stant­ly a­void in­ter­fer­ing with it.

verses.original: 及其有事也，又不足以取天下也。
verses.translation: If you in­ter­fere, youʼre un­fit to rule the world.
The sage con­stant­ly has no mind of his own.
He takes the mind of the peo­ple as his mind.
Heʼs good to good peo­ple
and al­so good to bad peo­ple,
thus he gains in good­ness.
He trusts trust­wor­thy peo­ple
and al­so trusts un­trust­wor­thy peo­ple,
thus he gains in trust.
If I had the least bit of knowl­edge,
I would walk on the great Way
and my on­ly fear would be straying from it.
The great Way is ver­y much lev­el,
but peo­ple ver­y much pre­fer moun­tain trails.
The court is full of splen­dor,
but the fields are full of weeds,
and the granaries are full of noth­ing;
their clothes are embroidered and col­or­ful,
their belts have sharp swords,
theyʼre stuffed with food,
and have mon­ey and possessions in ex­cess:
this is called rob­ber­y,
and rob­ber­y is cer­tain­ly not the Way.
Those who know it, donʼt talk a­bout it;
those who talk a­bout it, donʼt know it.
Gov­ern the state with jus­tice,
de­ploy the mil­i­tar­y with sur­prise,
and take the world with­out in­ter­fer­ence.

verses.original: 吾何以知其然也哉？以此：
verses.translation: How do I know this? From the fol­low­ing:
The world has man­y prohibitions and taboos,
and yet the peo­ple are full of pov­er­ty.
The peo­ple have man­y ben­e­fi­cial tools,
and yet the state and fam­i­ly are in­creas­ing­ly faint.
Peo­ple have man­y clev­er tricks,
and yet strange things in­creas­ing­ly hap­pen.
The laws are in­creas­ing­ly pub­li­cized,
and yet there are man­y thieves and robbers.
There­fore, in the words of the sage:
“I act with­out force, and the peo­ple trans­form them­selves.
I en­joy qui­et, and the peo­ple cor­rect them­selves.
I donʼt intefere, and the peo­ple pros­per them­selves.
I have no desires, and the peo­ple sim­pli­fy them­selves.”
Good for­tune perch­es on mis­for­tune;
mis­for­tune lurks be­neath good for­tune.
Who knows where it will end?
Noth­ing is ob­vi­ous.
Ob­vi­ous a­gain becomes sur­pris­ing;
good a­gain becomes mon­strous.
The peo­ple have been con­fused for a long time.
In governing the peo­ple and serv­ing Heav­en,
there is noth­ing like fru­gal­i­ty.
On­ly with fru­gal­i­ty can you sub­mit ear­ly.
Sub­mit­ting ear­ly is called re­peat­ed­ly ac­cu­mu­lat­ing vir­tue.
If you re­peat­ed­ly ac­cu­mu­late vir­tue, then there is noth­ing you canʼt o­ver­come.
The Way is the treas­ure of a good man,
and the shel­ter of a bad man.
Beau­ti­ful words can buy hon­or,
and good deeds can raise you a­bove others.
E­ven if a man is bad, how can you a­ban­don him?
At the emperorʼs cor­o­na­tion,
of­fer­ing jade discs brought in by a team of hors­es
is not as good as sit­ting still and of­fer­ing this Way.

verses.original: 古之所以貴此道者何也？
verses.translation: Why was this Way so val­u­a­ble to the ancients?
Is­nʼt it said, “Those who seek, with this will ob­tain,
and those who have guilt, with this will es­cape”?
There­fore itʼs the most val­u­a­ble thing in the world.
Act with­out forc­ing,
serve with­out in­ter­fer­ing,
sa­vor the fla­vor­less,
con­sid­er the small as great and the few as man­y,
re­spond to re­sent­ment with vir­tue.
Plan for some­thing dif­fi­cult while itʼs still eas­y.
Deal with some­thing great while itʼs still small.
The dif­fi­cult things of the world start off eas­y.
The great things of the world start off small.
There­fore, the sage nev­er does great things,
and thus he is a­ble to ac­com­plish great things.
He who makes promises light­ly is sure to have lit­tle trust,
and he who treats man­y things as eas­y is sure to have man­y difficul­ties.
There­fore, the sage treats things as dif­fi­cult,
and thus, in the end, noth­ing is dif­fi­cult.
Itʼs eas­y to hold what is at rest.
Itʼs eas­y to plan for what has­nʼt be­gun.
Itʼs eas­y to break what is brit­tle.
Itʼs eas­y to scat­ter what is ti­ny.
Deal with it be­fore it happens;
man­age it be­fore itʼs cha­ot­ic.
A tree thatʼs thick e­nough to em­brace rises from a ti­ny shoot.
A ter­race thatʼs nine stories tall rises from a heap of earth.
A wall thatʼs three hun­dred yards high begins at the ground be­neath your feet.
Those who rule it ru­in it.
Those who hold it lose it.

verses.original: 是以，聖人無爲也，故無敗也；
verses.translation: There­fore, the sage rules noth­ing and thus ruins noth­ing.
He holds on to noth­ing and thus loses noth­ing.

verses.original: 民之從事也，恆於其成而敗之。
verses.translation: Peo­ple u­su­al­ly fail in their endeavors on the verge of suc­cess.
There­fore we say, “If youʼre as care­ful at the end as you are at the be­gin­ning,
youʼll have no fail­ure.”
The sage desires not to de­sire,
and does­nʼt val­ue goods that are hard to ob­tain;
he learns not to stud­y,
and returns to what the mul­ti­tude has passed o­ver.
He could help all things to be nat­u­ral,
but dares not do it.

verses.original: 江海之所以能爲百谷王者，
verses.translation: The rivers and lakes are a­ble to be the kings of the valleys
be­cause of their skill at be­ing low.

verses.original: 是以聖人之欲上民也，必以其言下之；
verses.translation: There­fore, want­ing to be a­bove the peo­ple, the sage must speak to them hum­bly from be­low;

verses.original: 其欲先民也，必以其身後之。
verses.translation: want­ing to be be­fore the peo­ple, he must put him­self be­hind them.
There­fore, he dwells a­bove them yet the peo­ple donʼt feel that heʼs a bur­den.
He dwells be­fore them yet the peo­ple donʼt feel that heʼs an ob­struc­tion.
Eve­ry­one in the world delights in pro­mot­ing him and nev­er tires of him.
Itʼs be­cause he does­nʼt con­tend
that no one in the world can con­tend with him.
I con­stant­ly have three treasures which I hold and treas­ure:
the first is com­pas­sion,
the sec­ond is fru­gal­i­ty,
the third is not dar­ing to be pre­em­i­nent in the world.
Itʼs be­cause of com­pas­sion that I can be cou­ra­geous;
itʼs be­cause of fru­gal­i­ty that I can be gen­er­ous;

verses.original: 不敢爲天下先，故能爲成器長。
verses.translation: itʼs be­cause of not dar­ing to be pre­em­i­nent in the world that I can be head of all things.
Now, abandoning com­pas­sion to be cou­ra­geous,
abandoning fru­gal­i­ty to be gen­er­ous,
abandoning the rear to be in front:
this is courting death.
A skill­ful war­ri­or does­nʼt show his might.
A skill­ful fight­er does­nʼt get an­gry.
A skill­ful vic­tor does­nʼt en­gage his en­e­my.
A skill­ful em­ploy­er places him­self be­low others.
Those who are brave in dar­ing will die;
those who are brave in cau­tion will live.
In these two cases, one is ben­e­fi­cial and the oth­er is harm­ful.
Who understands why Heav­en hates what it does?
The Way of Heav­en does­nʼt fight yet wins skill­ful­ly,
does­nʼt speak yet responds skill­ful­ly,
is­nʼt summoned yet co­mes on its own,
is at ease yet plans skill­ful­ly.
The net of Heav­en is vast; it has a coarse mesh yet noth­ing slips through.

verses.original: 人之飢也，以其上食稅之多。
verses.translation: The peo­ple starve be­cause those a­bove con­sume too much in taxes.

verses.original: 百姓之不治也，以其上之有爲。
verses.translation: The peo­ple reb­el be­cause those a­bove in­ter­fere.

verses.original: 民之輕死也，以其上求生之厚。
verses.translation: The peo­ple scoff at death be­cause those a­bove de­mand so much from life.
While liv­ing, a man is sup­ple and soft,
but once dead, he is hard and rig­id.
While liv­ing, all things, grasses, and trees are sup­ple and crisp,
but once dead, they are withered and dry.
There­fore it is said: those who are hard and rig­id are the followers of death;
those who are sup­ple and soft are the followers of life.
There­fore, a rig­id ar­my wonʼt win,
and a rig­id tree will snap.
The Way of Heav­en is like an arch­er draw­ing his bow.
If itʼs too high, he presses down; if itʼs too low, he lifts up;
if there is ex­cess, he reduces it;
if there is not e­nough, he adds to it.

verses.original: 故天之道，損有餘而補不足。
verses.translation: The Way of Heav­en is al­so to re­duce what has ex­cess and add to what does­nʼt have e­nough.
The Way of man is dif­fer­ent:
he reduces what does­nʼt have e­nough and offers it to that which has ex­cess.

verses.original: 夫孰能有餘而有以取奉於天者乎？
verses.translation: Who can have ex­cess and of­fer it to Heav­en?
On­ly he who has the Way.
There­fore, the sage takes actions with­out claiming the results;
he succeeds with­out dwell­ing on it;
sim­i­lar­ly, he does­nʼt de­sire to make a dis­play of his wor­thi­ness.
When har­mo­ny is made af­ter great re­sent­ment,
there is al­ways some re­sent­ment remaining.
How can this be con­sid­ered good?

verses.original: 是以聖人執左契而不責於人。
verses.translation: There­fore, the sage keeps his part of the con­tract, but makes no demands on the oth­er par­ty.
The Way of Heav­en has no favorites,
itʼs con­stant­ly on the side of the good man.
Let there be a small state with few peo­ple.

verses.original: 使有十百人之器而勿用；
verses.translation: Let them have pow­er­ful tools and not use them.
Let the peo­ple take death se­ri­ous­ly and not mi­grate far a­way.
There are boats and vehicles but no rea­son to ride them.
There are ar­mor and weapons but no rea­son to pa­rade them.
Let the peo­ple keep their records with knot­ted string a­gain.
Their food is sweet,
their clothes are beau­ti­ful,
their homes are se­cure,
and their cus­toms are en­joy­a­ble.
Neighboring states can see each oth­er,
they can hear each otherʼs dogs and roosters,
yet the peo­ple grow old and die
with­out any deal­ings be­tween each oth­er.
Cred­i­ble words arenʼt el­o­quent;
el­o­quent words arenʼt cred­i­ble.
The skill­ful arenʼt polymaths;
those who are polymaths arenʼt skill­ful.
Those who know arenʼt learn­ed;
the learn­ed donʼt know.
The sage accumulates noth­ing.
The more he does for others, the greater his possessions.
The more he gives to others, the greater his a­bun­dance.
There­fore, the Way of Heav­en is to ben­e­fit with­out harming.
The Way of the sage is to act with­out contending.
